The American
fields.description: A gun-slinger from Americaâ€™s Wild West. They grew up with great privilege but abandoned it for the frontier life. Along the way, they picked up a curse that sometimes changes them into a feral beast. Throughout the game youâ€™ll be exploring how they came to leave their privileged life and why they eventually fled to London.

fields.name: The Undeniable
fields.description: An immortal being of incomparable physical beauty. They have been worshipped as a god for much of their lives and they walk through the world with an extreme sense of entitlement. Throughout the game youâ€™ll be exploring how they came to be a modern, urbane god.

fields.name: The Factotum
fields.description: A servant of one of the other hunters. They are a highly skilled operatorâ€”resourceful and practical. When the other hunters are mired in darkness, the Factotum is busy getting the job done. Throughout the game, youâ€™ll explore their professional past and how they came to be a servant.

fields.name: The Explorer
fields.description: A member of the upper classes. They made their name and fortune mapping the unexplored parts of the world for the Crown. They are also the rival of the criminal mastermind Hargrave House will eventually have to face. Throughout the game, youâ€™ll be exploring the story of a young man whose village was terrorized by the Explorer when the Explorer was camped there during an expedition.

fields.name: The Vessel
fields.description: A magic-user. They are in regular contact withâ€”and the obsession ofâ€”dark entities that give them their magical powers. Throughout the game, youâ€™ll explore their history with these dark entities, as well as with a coven of witches they used to be a member of but have since fled.

fields.case_files_subtitle: Being the most accurate accounts of the endeavours and accomplishments of the current representatives of the Hargrave House, as recorded by Mr. Eccles.

fields.name: The St. James's Street Ghost
fields.player_notes:
* **The Mask of the Unquiet**: Each hunter narrates a flashback to their childhood when they experienced a haunting.

**Clues:**

1. The boy, Roger, seems to grow older as Charles watches, and smiles unnervingly.
1. Oldest boy of the Buckleys, fell from the second floor landing, with limbs twisted exactly like the maid, Ginny.
1. The guest room door is always locked.
1. The attic room bursts into flames, but they do not burn.
1. Attic rooms wall contains the number 2063 in red colour.
fields.gm_notes: Ann-Elisabeth Tanner

fields.name: The Limehouse Lurker
fields.player_notes:
Jenny Johnston, the proprietor of an opium den in Limehouse, tells you a story that has not yet reached Scotland Yard or the papers: three people have been found dead in recent days, the bodies completely exsanguinated. !e first was a prostitute called Soho Jimmy, found in a dark corner of the opium den; the second was a young mother, Charla Bell, found in an alleyway behind the Limehouse School; and the third was a Chinese sailor, Zhao Donghai, found outside a pub near the Regentâ€™s Canal Dock, the Dog & Whistle. Jenny, an informal community leader in Limehouse, has been keeping the bodies in her basement; sheâ€™s hesitant to go to the authorities because she fears it will cause trouble for the small but thriving Chinese immigrant community in the district. She heard that Hargrave House has experience with matters such as this, and has asked for your help.


From Jenny's description of small, closely-spaced puncture marks on the victims' wrists, Mr. Baker is able to determine that this vampire is physically a child - but that does not mean it is young. Vampires never physically age beyond how old they were when they were â€œturned,â€ and an old vampire has to be handled in a very different way from a young one...

### Questions & opportunities:

* Is the vampire young or old? (Complexity: 4)
* IF IT IS OLD, WHERE IS THE VAMPIREâ€™S NEST? (Complexity: 4)

### Additional mask:

* **The Mask of the Sun**


### Clues


* Roman military unit painted on a wall of a room below the opium den's cold cellar
* Fragnance of lilies, petals on/in the three dead vampire victims
* Discarded clothes of a child at the opium den
* Fresh blood falling from heights
* Glass of milk with cookie on a plae (the sidealley behind the pub)

fields.name: The Creature of Cremorne Gardens
fields.player_notes:
Is the creature real or is it a hoax?

Threat mask: The Mask of Reverly

fields.name: The Curious Case of Dr Watson
fields.player_notes:
### Clues

* A book of ChtonicMonstorities (MASTERMIND)
* Sherlock Holmes' address on a black shiny calling card with golden letters (MASTERMIND)
* Onyx statuette of a animal threesome embrace (MASTERMIND)
* Shinyblack card with Invitation to "Evening of Revelations" for one guest (MASTERMIND)

fields.name: The Shoreditch Slugger
fields.player_notes:
### Clues

* Red Velvet cape

fields.name: The Coven
fields.player_notes:
The coven has arrived in London. !ey are here in the guise of a group of fortune-tellers and mediums calling itself the Fellowship of Dreamers, but you know the truth: they are very evil, very powerful, and very dangerous.

Mr. Baker knows that the ritual, when completed, will call forth the Antichrist.

You donâ€™t know where the coven is, but you know where theyâ€™ve been: the homes of several prominent members of society, where they were guests before performing seances and tarot card readings at the homeownersâ€™ fetes. !ose addresses are: 14 Brompton Road, 6 Boscobel Place, and the Rutland Gardens estate.

fields.name: Harold Beale
fields.description: A husband, a father, an accountant and an amateur mathematician
fields.player_notes:
* Constantly fiddling.
* Worried about money.
* Reached above his station acquiring this cheap house.
fields.gm_notes:
Clue: Harold's household ledger contains entries for strange household expenses he can't explain, like "thought-casting" and "dream-whisperer" and "pig gifts".

Reactions: Calls for Scotland Yard. Demands reimbursement for damages.

fields.name: Roger Beale
fields.player_notes: * Likes to give his friends tours of the ghost house.
fields.gm_notes:
Clue: A series of numbers written in an unusual place (behind wallpaper, in the ashes of a fire/in the dust on the mantel)

Reactions: Escapes the house, causing all kinds of concern and concentrating on wrong things.

fields.name: Mary Alice Beale
fields.player_notes:
* Quite bald for her age.
* What a curious fat little monkey she is.
fields.gm_notes:
Clue: A room appears to be on fire, but it is not.

Reactions: Chokes on something. Vomits all over a character.

fields.name: Alice Beale
fields.player_notes: * Typical housewife, seems to have nothing to contribute.
fields.gm_notes:
Clue: Same book keeps falling off the library shelf, a ghoulish novel about a wife who murders her husband.

Reactions: Accusation of improper behaviour. Hysterical about the safety of children. Revoke the hunters' invitation to the house.

fields.name: Pythagoras
fields.player_notes: * Nervous all the time family has lived in the house.
fields.gm_notes:
Clue: A series of numbers. A stack of love letters from another time.

Reaction: Goes berserk with fear, inflicting damage to character or Side character

fields.name: Irma Thicket
fields.player_notes:
* Came with the house.
* Already served Buckeys.
fields.gm_notes:
Clue: Rumors of an arranged marriage gone awry.

Reactions:

fields.name: Constance Head
fields.player_notes: * Nosy.
fields.gm_notes:
Clue: Rumours of an arranged marriage gone awry.

Reactions: Call the constable from before. Marks a character.

fields.name: The man in the sun mask
fields.description: A patron of the opium den

fields.name: Thomas Simpson
fields.gm_notes:
Pert mustache. Thinning hair. Nervous and excitable. Thomas is dismissive of or, at most, annoyed by, stories of the creature. His principle desire is to make money. He is very sensitive to comparisons with other, more successful pleasure gardens.

Quote: â€œCertainly Vauxhall Gardens was a spectacle in its dayâ€”I myself spent some time there before they, sadly, closedâ€”but our vision for Cremorne Gardens is much more ambitious. Did you know our dancing platform can accommodate up to 4,000 people?â€

fields.name: Herod Farsblet-Mogg
fields.gm_notes: Commanding voice, persistent shake in the left arm, civilian clothes of most military cut

fields.name: Alexander Kingdom Hardy
fields.gm_notes: Proud bearing, constantly filling his pipe, comes alive when telling war stories

fields.name: Mycroft Holmes
fields.gm_notes:
- Lives at Pall Mall
- Diogenes Club

Quotes:
- â€œAll lives end. All hearts are broken. Caring is not an advantage."
- "I do not suffer fools gladly, and I prefer to spend my time alone with a book and a decanter of brandy."

fields.name: Shinwell "Porky" Johnson
fields.player_notes: Air of lounging superiority. Clothes aiming at respectability but always failing.
fields.gm_notes:
leader of the Baker Street Irregulars. Speaks in questions. Former patient of Watson, with some ideas of â€œgoing straightâ€. When Watson needs some night work done, he can be found creeping around in dark alleys, conferring with police and prostitutes alike to find whateverâ€”or whoeverâ€”he needs. Heâ€™s a deft hand with a knife and maintains a loose confederation of bullies and catâ€™s paws in case violence is the remedy called for.

Quote: *â€œAre you going to continue being a thorn in my employerâ€™s side? Do you know what happens to people who cross him? What if I told you I happen when people cross him? Do you suppose I have a knife in my pocket? Would you guess Iâ€™ve a very deft hand with it?â€*

fields.name: Shoreditch Slugger
fields.player_notes: Big, bad enigma of a man with a mean, mean swing. Nearly seven feet tall and solid as stone. A Herculean body covered in scars.
fields.gm_notes:
He isnâ€™t much for talking; he lets his physical presence speak for him, commanding rooms and inspiring fear with sheer he# and coiled aggression. Per the rules of Bout Club, the other members donâ€™t know much, if anything, about his life outside of the fighting ring; probably heâ€™s just anoth-er one of themâ€”eking out a sorry existence in factories and East London tenements. Heâ€™s a recent Irish immigrant, they think; most havenâ€™t heard him speak for long enough to know for sure. !eyâ€™ve heard his real name is Jack. Or Liam. Or Cormac.  !e Shoreditch Slugger isnâ€™t completely physically invulnerableâ€”he bleeds as red as anyoneâ€”but he does have an uncanny ability to power through pain and an abnor-mal healing factor. He can and has survived blows that would kill a lesser man. He relishes victory and will never back down "om an opportunity to crush a challenger. In fact, he finds it a great, great pleasure to be a cannon in a cardboard world.

IF HARGRAVE HOUSE IGNORES THE SHOREDITCH SLUGGER..

Word of the undefeated Slugger will reach the Mastermind, who takes a special interest in him. After this !reat is active for three Night phases, narrate a scene in which the Slugger comes to the attentionâ€”and fascinationâ€”of the Mastermind. !is scene should inform the players that during the next Day phase, the Master-mind will be meeting with the Slugger to make him an offer he canâ€™t refuse. If the !reat is not resolved a#er the following Night phase, narrate a scene in which the Slugger accepts the offer and becomes a Servant of the Mastermind. !e Slugger ceases attending Bout Club. !is !reat is no longer active nor can it be resolved.

fields.name: Bram Fuller
fields.gm_notes:
Unusually pretty under the bruises. Defiant glare. Smells faintly of the stables. Bram faced the Slugger recently and survived without serious injury only because he conceded the fightâ€”a Bout Club first. Technically this is not against the rules, but he is nonetheless viciously ridiculed for it.

Quote: â€œCall me a coward one more time and I swear youâ€™ll regret it.â€

fields.name: Brick
fields.player_notes: Built squat and solid, like his namesake. Bald head. Never smiles
fields.gm_notes:
If a hunter has the Darkened !reshold marked or the Condition Most-Beloved and presents in a masculine way, heâ€™ll recognize something kindred in them and spare them the interrogation at the door, instead gru"y ushering them in and instructing them to talk to Jester.

Quote: â€œNo â€˜Bout Clubâ€™ here. Move along.â€

fields.name: Colin "Jester" Yardley
fields.player_notes: A natural showman. Always smiling. Always covered in blood.
fields.gm_notes:
Jester is o#en yelling through a loud hailer and speaks unduly formally, referring to the members of Bout Club as â€œgents.â€ Jester isnâ€™t the founder of the clubâ€”no one seems to remember who isâ€”but he has become the de facto leader because he chooses the venues and is the loudest, and that counts for something. He has a marked sadistic streak and is fiercely protective of his hard-won leadership position; a challenge to it is the only thing that will wipe the grin off his face.

Quote: â€œWhat do you think, gents, should we make this fight more interesting? Grigory, bring out the knuckle dusters youâ€™ve procured for us, if  you please.â€

fields.name: Denny Baker
fields.player_notes: Smells of cheap liquor. Bloodshot eyes. Definitely not crying.
fields.gm_notes:
inneas Byrd was Dennyâ€™s best %iend. Since Finneasâ€™s death following a particularly brutal bout with the Shoreditch Slugger, Denny has been channeling his grief into anger and drink. He will do something very unwise, very soon to exact revenge on the Slugger. !e first hunter who wins a physical fight against Denny will receive a memento given in Finneasâ€™s honor; they should ask another hunter what it is then add it to their Personal Quarters.

Quote: â€œâ€˜Invincibleâ€™ they say he is. I bet a pistol says different. I bet the noose down at the Old Bailey says different. All these dolts are too scared to go to Scotland Yard about â€˜im. Bout Club rulesâ€”p".â€

fields.name: Francis Oakes
fields.player_notes: Anxious demeanor. Tight cotton chest bindings under a tattered vest. An anchor tattoo on lean muscle.
fields.gm_notes:
Francis is a very recent inductee into Bout Club. He takes the clubâ€™s covenant of brotherhood and secrecy very seriously and is extremely vigilant against being perceived as weak. He will steadfastly refuse to associate with any hunter heâ€™s witnessed losing a fight for fear of their inadequacy being projected onto him. !e first hunter who wins a physical fight against Francis will receive a Clue, no roll necessary

Quote: â€œYouâ€™ll never catch me just giving up a fight like Bram did. I donâ€™t care if  I die. I just donâ€™t think any man should die without scars, you know?â€

fields.name: Pettigrew
fields.player_notes: Killed by Eliza in the fight club

fields.name: Elsie Willow
fields.player_notes: Red hair, laughs a lot, moth-eaten dress

fields.name: Kip Longfellow
fields.player_notes: Quite short, smells of hay, weirdly red

fields.name: Silas Gren
fields.player_notes: Muscular, wears an apron, looks older than he is

fields.name: Velma Thenwicket
fields.player_notes: Pretty, usually stern, always tired

fields.name: Pig's Ear
fields.player_notes: Hirsute, smells... bad, surprisingly poetic

fields.name: Barrel Staves
fields.player_notes: An absolute unit

fields.name: Achibald Sapthorn
fields.player_notes: A rare pensionate soldier, still stern, still connected

fields.name: Brother Samuel
fields.player_notes: Clean-cut, smells of juniper, soft hands

fields.name: The Basement
fields.description: The basement of the townhouse contains the kitchen and the servantsâ€™ quarters.
fields.player_notes: * Celtic runes painted in the top corners of rooms to ward off ghosts.

fields.name: Front room
fields.description: The first of two main rooms on the ground floor; contains a small library and enough seating for the family and a few visitors.

fields.name: Dining room
fields.description: The second of two main rooms on the ground floor; features a long, polished table that can seat up to eight, a curio cabinet, and serving trolley.
fields.player_notes: * Low-quality mirror.

fields.name: Bedrooms
fields.description: There are four bedrooms in total on the second floor, one for each of Harold, Alice, Roger, and guests.

fields.name: Nursery
fields.description: The attic has been transformed into a nursery and decorated in soft, pastel colors.
fields.player_notes: Master Charles "transformed" the room into... an uglier version of itself (2063 behind the peeling wallpaper)

fields.name: Jenny Johnston's
fields.player_notes:
- Better beds with privacy screens for the more well-to-do at front, successively worse places for poorer patrons
- Shadowy corners each seem to have someone standing
- Very differently dressed people, very different-looking shoes left at the door
fields.gm_notes: Dim and smoky. A heavy, ammonia-like smell. People lounging on cushions.

fields.name: The Limehouse school
fields.gm_notes: Filthy children all over the place. A frustrated mistress storming away from a group of girls (not) learning to sew. The smell of unwashed bodies.

fields.name: The Dog & Whistle
fields.gm_notes: Dull, brass fixtures. A stack of tin mugs. A painting of a dog (but no whistle).

fields.name: Regent's canal dock
fields.gm_notes: Coal dust on everything. Sailors playing dice games. Prostitutes and tinkers peddling their respective wares.

fields.name: The Dancing Platform
fields.description: A large pagoda, crammed with revelers at night. Hundreds of lanterns glowing overhead. A dance floor scuffed by thousands of shoes.
fields.gm_notes: Paint the Scene: T A sense of wild abandonâ€”of an unshackling of the social constraints of the dayâ€”hangs in the air here. What do you see or otherwise perceive that indicates this?

fields.name: The American Bowling Saloon
fields.description: !e thundering crash of bowling balls hitting their mark. Pinboys dashing to and "o. !e slightly stilted sound of the barrel piano cranking out a â€œjauntyâ€ tune.
fields.gm_notes: Paint the Scene:!is place embraces â€œAmericanaâ€ and the idea of the Wild West, but to an American, it would all seem a little off. How do we know that?

fields.name: The Banqueting Hall
fields.description: Waiters in well-tailored black livery. Dazzlingly white tablecloths. Stacks of fine crystal goblets next to enormous casks of wine.
fields.gm_notes: Paint the Scene:Yo u   s m e l l   s o m e t h i n g   s a v o r y   a n d   u n c t u o u s   a s   y o u   s t e p   i n s i d e .   W h a t   i s   i t ?

fields.name: The Promenade
fields.description: Well-manicured lawns. Neatly-ordered flower beds. Ancient trees.
fields.gm_notes: Paint the Scene:Yo u   s e e   s o m e t h i n g   t r u l y   b e a u t i f u l   a l o n g   t h e   p r o m e n a d e .   W h a t   i s   i t ?

fields.name: The Hedge Maze
fields.description: Towering hedges that seem to block you off from the outside world. Stone benches and fountains. The occasional animal.
fields.gm_notes: Paint the Scene: Unbeknownst to people entering it the first time, the hedge maze is designed to scare patrons. What frightening display do you see when you turn a corner?

fields.name: Cheyne Walk
fields.description: The smell of roasting coffee beans. The whistle of steamer ships in the distance.The hopelessly stupid giggling of young lovers.
fields.gm_notes: Paint the Scene: This street along the harbor, and just a few hundred feet from Cremorne Gardens, will become the center of an artistic movement in London in a few short years. What do you see right now that hints at this future?

fields.name: The Dining Room
fields.description: You donâ€™t take meals together often, but tonight is an exception. Whatâ€™s on the menu?

fields.name: The Reception Hall
fields.description: Do you feel unsettled or at home when you enter Hargrave House? What do you perceive in the reception hall that reinforces this feeling?

fields.name: The Trophy Room
fields.description: There were hunters living in Hargrave House before you; trophies from their encounters with the supernatural can be found here. Describe one.

fields.name: The Map Room
fields.description: This room is littered with mapsâ€”of the city, of England, of the worldâ€”and some of them are highly unusual. Name one and describe why itâ€™s so strange.

fields.name: The Salon
fields.description: What do you see in this room that makes it the most comfortable spot in the entire house?

fields.name: The Music Room
fields.description: A former hunter in residence once used this room to wrangle a spirit using the power of music. There are still subtle signs of the struggle in this room. What are they?

fields.name: The Library
fields.description: Of all the rooms in Hargrave House, none feel more â€œunstuckâ€ than this one. As you enter the library, what do you see or experience that feels a little... off?
fields.player_notes:
- Uncannily clean and dustless
- No one knows how shelves the library has
- Feels like you are never quite alone in the library
- Random books pulled forward

fields.name: The Conservatory
fields.description: A former hunter in residence turned out to be the legendary killer Roger the Reaver. This was his favorite room in Hargrave House. Looking around, how do you know that?

fields.name: The Gardens
fields.description: eing in this space is like being totally disconnected from the stink and grime of London. Is that reassuring to you or does it make you feel uncomfortable? Why?

fields.name: The Ballroom
fields.description: Hargrave House once hosted a ball for a group of visitors from the fae realm. Even today there are subtle reminders of that night in this room. What are they?

fields.name: The Kitchen
fields.description: The kitchen existed long before the rest of the house, having been part of a pub that stood on the spot before Belgravia was redeveloped to be a residential district.
fields.player_notes: What do you see that reminds you of this fact?

fields.name: The Basement
fields.description: This space is cluttered with the belongings of long-dead hunters who used to live in Hargrave House. What do you take from it? Add it to your Personal Quarters.

fields.name: The Servants' Quarters
fields.description: These rooms are mostly empty nowadays as, given the placeâ€™s history, very few people want to work at Hargrave House.
fields.player_notes: They have most frequently been used as a place for trysts between the houseâ€™s residents. What here reminds you of that?

fields.name: The Tarot Card Reading of Ms. Lydia Wainwright
fields.player_notes:
Lydia Wainwright is a young woman of nineteen, born into a respectable family. Her mother has commanded her to marry Edgar Thornton, the son of a wealthy industrialist, but her heart belongs to Samuel, a poor, but very handsome, chimney sweep. Lydia has snuck off in the night to the home of a fortune teller, seeking guidance on the matter.

I - *Paint the Scene:* As Lydia enters the home of the fortune teller, what do we see that shows this place has real magic? *kaikki*

II - The first two cards drawn in the five-card spread are the Lovers and the Ace of Wands, the latter of which is typically associated with passion. Speaking in the voice of the fortune teller, begin telling Lydia what you see in the cards. *Julle*

III - The next two cards drawn are the Five of Swords, typically associated with violence, and the Fool, which represents the beginning of a journey. Continue the fortune tellerâ€™s card reading. *Pasi*

IV - The last card drawn is the Devil, representing the seduction of the material world and other earthly pleasures. Continue your reading and then tell Lydia, definitively, what she must do. *Janne*

fields.name: The Cult of the Pig
fields.player_notes:
A secretive cult dedicated to the pagan swine god Mocâ€™h has gathered in a fashionable salon on this holy night to make offerings to their porcine deity.

I - *Paint the Scene:* How has this otherwise sumptuously decorated salon been changed to make it a ritual space dedicated to an ancient pagan pig god?

II - Mocâ€™h demands a sacrifice of riches. What does the cult offer him? Describe the manner of the offering. *Pasi*

III - Mocâ€™h demands a sacrifice of status. What does the cult offer him? Describe the manner of the offering. *Janne*

IV - Mocâ€™h demands a sacrifice of blood. What does the cult offer him? Describe the manner of the offering. *Julle*

fields.name: One Armed Assistance
fields.gm_notes: Paint the scene: What in the club tells us that the batmen think that they are the true backbone of British military?

fields.name: Diogenes Club
fields.gm_notes: â€œThere are many men in London, you know, who, some from shyness, some from misanthropy, have no wish for the company of their fellows. Yet they are not averse to comfortable chairs and the latest periodicals. It is for the convenience of these that the Diogenes Club was started, and it now contains the most unsociable and unclubbable men in town. No member is permitted to take the least notice of any other one. Save in the Stranger's Room, no talking is, under any circumstances, allowed, and three offenses, if brought to the notice of the committee, render the talker liable to expulsion. My brother was one of the founders, and I have myself found it a very soothing atmosphere.â€

fields.name: The Prison Hulk at Woolwich
fields.player_notes:
Moored near the industrial town of Woolwich are a number of hollowed-out old warships that serve as temporary prisons for convicts set to be transferred to Australia and other penal colonies. One of these â€œprison hulksâ€ is the HMS Bellorophon, now called the HMS Captivity. A too-young cook is walking above and below deck, passing out the eveningâ€™s portion of hard biscuits and pea soup.

1. *Paint the Scene*: How do we know the Captivity is a nightmare of filth and desperation?

2. Narrate a scene in which we see the convicts at leisure. How do they entertain themselves? How do they maintain their connection to God and society, if at all?

3. Narrate a scene in which we see a convict being punished by a shipâ€™s officer. What did the convict do? How is the punishment being carried out?

4. Narrate a scene in which we see a convict finding comfort and companionship within the bulkheads of the _Captivity_.

fields.name: Brown's Hotel
fields.player_notes:
None of the 117 rooms at Brownâ€™s Hotel on Albermarle Street are the same, though they each have housed some of the most fashionable people youâ€™ll find in London or anywhere. A concierge, Teddy Miller, delights in spying on the hotelâ€™s posh clientele.

1. Teddy puts his ear up against the door of a wealthy young bachelor. What does he hear that makes him desperately want the life of this young bachelor? Julle
2. Teddy rummages through the personal effects of an actress staying at the hotel while she is out. What does he find that makes him desire her or desire to be her? Kukka
3. Teddy draws a hot bath for a pair of good-looking young men staying in the same room. In what ways does Teddy help bring the erotic subtext of this scene to the fore? Janne
4. Teddy returns to his tiny, dingy flat in East London. What do we see in Teddyâ€™s apartment that shows how he tries to incorporate bits of glamor into his dull, gray life? Pasi
